doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/The Financials Statement Spotlight on French Banks again Insurance 1H25 earnings Week VThe Financials Statement Spotligh_2025-08-29

passages.text: Spotlight on French Bank (again); Insurance 1H'25 earnings Week V

Secondary spreads saw a touch of weakness this week amidst renewed sovereign volatility and broader geopolitical disruptions. In particular, EAT1 widened 11bps and SAT1 20bps in the Wed- Wed period, while Tier 2 gave up 7bps, and both Senior tranches 3/4bps apiece, slightly underperforming their non- financial senior comparable. Primary markets meanwhile reopened in earnest, with \(\sim \in 8.5bn\) placed with investors.

In Insurance, also, a new issue was placed with investors during the week (along with a further T2 transaction in the market at time of writing). The latter comes on the follow from Legal & General's announced tender at par for any- and- all of its outstanding 600mn LGEN 5.500% 44- 64 T2 (gf) - one of a dwindling number of grandfathered bonds under the Solvency II transitional arrangements that has a call date beyond the ending of the grandfathering period (end of December 2025). We set out the list within this piece.

Spotlight on French Banks (again): With the weekend's political newsflow bringing forward the market's expected timeline for renewed French sovereign volatility, and the corresponding focus on the region's banks, we take the opportunity to set out our thoughts on valuations within the complex here, and set out a number of trade recommendations, focused predominantly on Subordinated (AT1 and Tier 2) risk.

Insurance 1H25 - Week 5: Ageas, Prudential PLC, Uniqa and Vienna all delivered 1H25 results that were supportive of their credit quality this week; with improved underwriting profitability, strong cash and capital generation, boosting already defensive solvency coverage levels across the cohort.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
Europe Corporate Credit - Banking & Financial Services (IG)
Gareth Davies, CFA AC (44- 20) 3493 0672

Secondary markets soften, while primary fires back to life
Deja vu kicks in this week following the weekend's political events

Secondary spreads saw a touch of weakness this week amidst renewed sovereign volatility and broader geopolitical disruptions. In particular, EAT1 widened 11bps and SAT1 20bps in the Wed- Wed period, while Tier 2 gave up 7bps, and both Senior tranches 3/4bps apiece, slightly underperforming their non- financial senior comparable. Primary markets meanwhile reopened in earnest, with \(\sim \mathrm{E8.5bn}\) placed with investors.

With the weekend's political newsflow bringing forward the market's expected timeline for renewed French sovereign volatility, the region's banks have naturally also seen an earlier than expected return to investor focus this week. Despite liquidity constrained conditions in the early part of the week, all parts of the capital structure did see some spread widening on the follow, with SUB CDS for the three National Champions as much as 9/10bps wider over the week, AT1 as much as 0.75- 1pt lower, and remaining Tier 2 and Senior cash tranches also marginally underperforming the broader sector.

Though we would not seek to trivialise the impact that any tail political outcomes (primarily a surprise call to parliamentary elections) could have on market sentiment, under central scenarios (e.g. selection of another centrist PM), we would suggest further fallout to valuations should be relatively contained, for two reasons.

First, as compared to last summer when President Macron called for a snap election, the banks themselves are fundamentally in much stronger shape today, with 2Q numbers (ACAFP and SOCGEN here, BNPhere) showing a much- improved revenue mix, with stabilised retail incomes and strength in other business lines helping deliver mid- single digit growth in revenues y/y despite the reversal of CIB tailwinds in 1Q. Second, as we illustrate in Figure 4 and Figure 5 below, French risk does generically still embed some risk premium relative to pre '24 snap election levels, having unwound much of its outperformance from late 2024's wides since May this year.
Figure 4: French Tier 2 spreads vs overall Tier 2 index bps
Figure 5: Senior French spreads (Bail-In and Sr Pref combined), vs overall Senior index
As such, rather than a wholesale reduction in French bank risk, we would suggest investors only reposition a little more defensively within the opportunity set itself,

improving the 'quality' of paper held. From a single name perspective, we maintain a preference within the 'big three' for ACAFP over BNP and SOCGEN, consistent with our broader preference for more retail- geared names over higher beta IBs, however we would suggest that in the nearer term political risk context, reducing duration, moving up the cap structure, or improving reset protection likely carries just as much value. From a tranche perspective meanwhile, we would reiterate our previously suggested playbook at times of sovereign volatility, of seeing better risk/reward generally in 'buying the dip' in subordinated paper, over senior risk (rating sensitive, and technically constrained by widening sovereign spreads), and accordingly focus predominantly on AT1 and Tier 2 below.
We set out a few positioning recommendations in AT1, focusing predominantly on improving reset protection within the complex
In AT1, we think two instruments across the two currency cohorts (Figure 6and Figure 7 ) appear relatively attractive:

1) ACAFP 6.500% \(\mathbb{C}\mathrm{sep}29\) (421bp reset) at 282bps STC/5.2% YTC, screening cheap to both BNP \(\mathbb{C}29\) and \(30s\) ( \(\sim 38 / 18\) bps spread pickup respectively for just \(\sim 45\) bps lower reset), and to its own \(\mathbb{S}\) comparable, offering \(\sim 100\) bp better reset than ACAFP \(4.70\%\) Mar'29 (324bp reset), for comparable spread on a cross-currency adjusted basis (the \(\mathbb{S}\) instrument at \(\mathbb{Z} + 302\) bps unadjusted).

2) SOCGEN 10.00% \(S\) Nov'28 (545bp reset) at 303bps STC/6.5% YTC, clearly appealing against its own spread-reset 'curve' in Figure 7, with SOCGEN 6.75% \(\mathbb{S}\) Apr'28 (393bp reset) offering only 40bps pickup for a \(>150\) bps reset difference.

We meanwhile think one bond in particular within the complex screens rich: BNP 4.625% \(S\) Jan'27 (320bp reset) at \(\mathbb{Z} + 198\) bps/5.6% YTC, both against its own reset curve, but also by comparison to, for instance, ACAFP \(4.000\%\) Dec'27 (437bp reset) at \(\mathbb{Z} + 219\) bps (unadjusted). We would consider this our preferred BNP- into- ACAFP switch currently in AT1, with our previously recommended switch between the \(S\) 34s having since performed (previously flat, BNP now 25bps wider).
Figure 6: French EAT1 relative value
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 7: French SAT1 relative value
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Consistent with our broader asset class recommendation, we see opportunities for AT1- Tier 2 decompression...
Notwithstanding our recommendations above, we would start by noting that the French Tier 2 space as a whole offers a number of opportunities for investors to move up the
capital structure at relatively limited spread cost, particularly within BNP's curve, as below:

1) Switch out of BNP \(4.625\%\) \(\) Jan'27\(320bp reset) at an unadjusted Z+198bps [same instrument screening rich within AT1 above], and into BNP 2.500\% €Mar'27-32 Tier 2 (160bp reset) at Z+97bps, i.e. at \~2.1x spread ratio\)
2) Switch out of BNP \(8.000\%\) \(\) Aug'31\(372bp reset) at an unadjusted Z+325bps, into BNP 3.945\% €Feb'32-37 (165bp reset) at Z+159bps, i.e. at \~2.1x spread ratio\)
3) Switch out of BNP \(4.625\%\) \(\) Feb'31\(334bps reset) at an unadjusted Z+352bps, into BNP 6.3175\% €Nov'30-35 (180bp reset) at Z+182bps, i.e. at \~2.0x spread ratio\)
... and also see pockets of outright 'within tranche' value.
Away from these, we see pockets of 'outright' value in French Tier 2, namely:
1) ACAFP 5.500% Aug'28-33 (225bp reset), continuing to trade flat to BNP 0.875% Aug'28-33 (117bp reset) at \~Z+120bps

2) Short call BPCE Tier 2's, including BPCEGP 1.500% Oct'26-42 (175bp reset) at Z+128bps, or for less 'tail' extension risk, BPCEGP 2.250% Mar'27-32 (175bps reset) at Z+103bps, both wide to the name's broader curve.
We resume coverage of BPCE with a Neutral recommendation

After a period of restriction we are moving our BPCE rating from UW to Neutral, taking a more constructive view of the name amidst ongoing efforts for geographic diversification. Though we maintain a Neutral recommendation on closest peer BFCM, we would also express a soft preference for BPCE at these levels, seeing for instance value in switching out of BFCM 4.00% Jan'30 (175bp reset) at Z+149bps, into BPCEGP 5.125% Jan'30-35 (250bps reset) at Z+157bps. Risks to our recommendation centre around execution of ongoing M&A.
Figure 8: French Callable €Tier 2 relative value bps
Source: J.P. Morgan.
We suggest a selective approach in Senior, led by supply considerations.
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Though we sought to focus predominantly here on subordinated risk, we would point Senior investors toward our July update on supply expectations for the remainder of the year, to help inform relative positioning between names and tranches. As one example, we note in Figure 9 above that in the callable Bail-In Senior curve, ACAFP continues to appeal in the context of its completed issuance plans in NPS, vs peers.
One new issue priced, one in the market, and a long- dated Solvency I tender operation

One new issue priced with investors during the week (along with a further T2 transaction in the market at time of writing). Munich Re placed its €1.25bn MUNRE 4.125% 35- 46 T2 tranche at MS+147bps, some 28bps inside of IPTs of 175a. Elsewhere, Legal & General announced a tender (and new issue) at par for any- and- all of its outstanding €600mn LGEN 5.500% 44- 64 T2 (gf). The bond is one of a dwindling number of grandfathered bonds under the Solvency II transitional arrangements that has a call date beyond the ending of the grandfathering period (end of December 2025) and had either not been already tendered down or made compliant with Solvency II standards (see Table 4 below).

Another four reporters this week, with all delivering improved underwriting performance leading to boosted bottom lines
Ages (AGSBB) 1H25: Improved profits, strong capital and cash generation and good solvency cover at Ages

Earnings: Ages reported insurance revenues of €3.7bn for 1H25 (€3.6bn, \(+4\%\) y/y). The non- life combined ratio came in at \(92.1\%\) (94%, - 1.9pp), largely due to a more benign loss experience from Belgian weather events. The ISR was therefore €602mn (€533mn, \(+13\%\) y/y). Net investment and finance results came in at €1.27bn (€1.26bn, \(+1.1\%\) y/y), which combined with insurance underwriting profits led to a net result of €677mn (€642mn, \(+5.5\%\) y/y). Capital & Leverage: Ages reported an SCR of \(240\%\) (218%, \(+22\) pp) with the intraperiod change due to capital raise (both equity and credit) that occurred in 1H25 associated with the purchase of the UK's secure business. Pro forma, the SCR would be \(\sim 205\%\) . Financial leverage has increased to \(22.4\%\) (17.6% as at FY24, \(+4.8\) pp), reflective of the 'secure issuance'.
Prudential PLC (PRUFIN) 1H25: Solid execution by Prudential in 2Q25

Earnings: Prudential PLC reported business segment profits of \(52bn\) ( \(1.8bn, +6\%\) ) for the first six months, driven by the performance of its large Hong Kong business ( \(587mn, +16\%\) ) and augmented by its Singapore division ( \(348mn, +1\%\) ). This was sourced from gross insurance revenues of \(5.3bn\) ( \(5.0bn, +7\%\) ) and an ISR of \(1.24bn\) ( \(1.1bn, +16\%\) ). Asset Management also added \(158mn\) ( \(155mn, +2\%\) ). Net investment results were \(896mn\) for the period ( \(167mn, n/a\) ), leading to PAT of \(1.4bn\) ( \(182mn, n/a\) ).
- Capital & Leverage: (Hong Kong) GWS coverage was 267% (280% at FY24, -13pp) at the end of the period, with financial leverage of 14% (13% at FY24, +1pp).
Uniqa (UQA) 1H25: Good set of results from Uniqa in 1H25

- Earnings: Austria's Uniqa reported GWP of €4.4bn for the first half (€4.1bn in 1H24, +10%), of which its P&C operations delivered €2.7bn of topline income (€2.4bn, +12%), Health a further €811mn (€758mn, +7%) and the Life business the final €862mn (€816mn, +5.7%). In terms of Insurance Revenues, the group reported 1H25 values of €3.5bn (€3.2bn, +9%). With a combined ratio of 90.5% in the non-Life book (91.7%, -1.2pp), the ISR was €378mn (€307mn, +23%). With financial results notably lower at €88mn (€129mn, -32%), institutional net income came in at €233mn (€221mn, +5.3%).- Capital & Leverage: In terms of capitalisation, the Group reported an SCR of 284% (266% at 1H24; 265% at FY24), versus a management target of 180-230%.
Vienna Insurance Group (VIGAV) 1H25: Significant improvement from Vienna as underwriting profitability up

- Earnings: Peer insurer Vienna also reported during the week, showing topline GWP of €8.6bn (€7.9bn, +8.7%) with insurance revenues of €6.4bn (€5.9bn, +8%), with intra-period growth primarily driven by increased penetration in CEE P&C markets. The combined ratio for the first six months was 91.9% (93.3% in 1H24, -1.4pp), which led to a group ISR of €696mn (€585mn, +19%). Net financial results were €256mn (€185mn, +38%), which combined to deliver PAT of €387mn (€352mn, +10%).
- Capital & Leverage: The group reported an SCR of 278% (261% as at FY24).

For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

A history of J.P. Morgan investment recommendations disseminated during the preceding 12 months can be accessed on the Research & Commentary page of http://www.jpmorganmarkets.com where you can also search by analyst name, sector or financial instrument.

J.P. Morgan uses a bond- level rating system that incorporates valuations (relative value) and our fundamental view on the security. Our fundamental credit view of an issuer is based on the company's underlying credit trends, overall creditworthiness and our opinion on whether the issuer will be able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable. We analyze, among other things, the company's cash flow capacity and trends and standard credit ratios, such as gross and net leverage, interest coverage and liquidity ratios. We also analyze profitability, capitalization and asset quality, among other variables, when assessing financials. Analysts also rate the issuer, based on the rating of the benchmark or representative security. Unless we specify a different recommendation for the company's individual securities, an issuer recommendation applies to all of the bonds at the same level of the issuer's capital structure. We may also rate certain loans and preferred securities, as applicable. This report also sets out within it the material underlying assumptions used. We use the following ratings for bonds (issues), issuers, loans, and preferred securities: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark). J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Sovereign Research uses Marketweight, which is equivalent to Neutral. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this particular security or issuer because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. For CDS, we use the following rating system: Long Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to exceed the relevant index, sector or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to match the relevant index, sector or benchmark); and Short Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector or benchmark).
